responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Directory Traversal in package download script
    analysis: |
      The `wget` command in several `package.sh` scripts allows an attacker to
      control the output directory. By setting `PACKAGE_URL` to a carefully
      crafted URL, an attacker can write arbitrary files to the filesystem.
      For example, an attacker could set `PACKAGE_URL` to
      `https://attacker.com/../../etc/passwd` and gain control of the target system.
    cwe: CWE-22
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - packaging/vendor/dragino/LG308/package.sh
      - packaging/vendor/multitech/conduit/package.sh
      - packaging/vendor/tektelic/kona/package.sh
      - packaging/vendor/cisco/IXM-LPWA/package.sh
      - packaging/vendor/kerlink/keros-gws/package.sh
    classification: very promising
  - headline: Unquoted variable in post-install.sh
    analysis: |
      The `$LOG_DIR` variable in the `create_logdir` function is used in a
      `mkdir -p` command without being quoted. While this might not be directly
      exploitable, it is a bad practice that could lead to unexpected behavior.
    cwe: CWE-428
    function_names:
      - create_logdir
    filenames:
      - packaging/scripts/post-install.sh
    classification: not promising
```

leads.headline: Directory Traversal in package download script
leads.analysis:
The wget command in several package.sh scripts allows an attacker to
control the output directory. By setting PACKAGE_URL to a carefully
crafted URL, an attacker can write arbitrary files to the filesystem.
For example, an attacker could set PACKAGE_URL to
https://attacker.com/../../etc/passwd and gain control of the target system.

leads.headline: Unquoted variable in post-install.sh
leads.analysis:
The $LOG_DIR variable in the create_logdir function is used in a
mkdir -p command without being quoted. While this might not be directly
exploitable, it is a bad practice that could lead to unexpected behavior.
